Comments_List: Theory of distributed systems, literally THEORY.

I got a broad view of the theory of distributed systems, which I very much needed for my PhD research. I became familiar with the way distributed systems people think and with which they approach and analyze problems, the standard models used in the field, and what the interesting questions are. I learned that careful case analysis, although tedious and unpleasant at times, can bring you far in terms of proving theorems (in the discrete world at least). But I would say that the most important thing this course teaches is a distributed way of thinking and of analyzing and designing algorithms, which is radically different from the sequential one we are usually taught, but nevertheless is used in practice all the time, and so is important for a Computer Scientist to be familiar with.
I learned about the theory of distributed systems and how to reason about problems in this area.

It helps if your research interest lies in this field.
But it's too challenging.

Strengths:
Clear separation of material between lectures.
Very good notes.

Weakness:
The course could be more connected to reality (if not at the real systems-application level, since it is a "Theory" course, at least in a way that would show more its practical usefulness and implications where these exist).
Although this is a pure theory course, I was still expecting some hands-on assignments in distributed systems applications.

The material in this course was very interesting. I think there could have been more assignments to keep the course more engaging. Otherwise, the assignments were great and really helped reinforce the material from class.
Only if you are a theory guy.
Definitely yes. Only to somebody who is willing to work though, and who is interested enough in the subject. I believe it is one of the courses to remember after graduating.
If you like theoretical CS and have interest in distributed systems, I definitely recommend this course.
Yes, the material was interesting and Prof. Aspnes teaches it really well.
Yes. The professor definitely knows what he is talking about and he cares about teaching it.
